phrases.usage: Use this phrase to establish the timeframe and introduce the primary subject of your narrative.
phrases.example: Last weekend, I attended a professional seminar because I wanted to improve my leadership skills.

phrases.usage: Use these sequential connectors to provide a clear chronological structure to your story.
phrases.example: First I registered for the event, then I attended the keynote speech, and after that I participated in a group discussion.

phrases.usage: Use this phrase to signal the conclusion of your experience or the final result of your actions.
phrases.example: In the end, I received a certificate of completion so I felt very proud of my progress.

phrases.usage: Use this expression to describe your emotional state or internal reaction to the events.
phrases.example: I felt motivated because the speakers provided very practical advice for my career.

phrases.usage: Use this structure to offer a logical explanation for why an activity was enjoyable.
phrases.example: It was fun because I met many interesting colleagues, so we exchanged many creative ideas.

phrases.usage: Use this transitional phrase to describe a subsequent event and maintain the flow of the story.
phrases.example: What happened next was an informal networking session where we discussed future collaborations.

phrases.usage: Use this to specify the approximate time an event occurred within your schedule.
phrases.example: Around 4 p.m., the main session concluded so we transitioned to the closing ceremony.

keyVocabulary.definition: Achieving or producing a significant amount or result.
To organize different elements or people so they work together effectively.
Feeling a sense of completion or success after finishing a task.
Time available for ease and relaxation rather than work.
To work together with others to achieve a common goal.
